abstract.p: Andy Webster reviews film Wind Chill, directed by Gregory Jacobs; Ashton Holmes and Emily Blunt star; photo (M)

block.p: Opened yesterday in New York, Los Angeles, Phoenix, Seattle, Dallas, Houston, Atlanta, Miami, Chicago and Minneapolis. Directed by Gregory Jacobs 87 minutes

Of Gregory Jacobs's thriller ''Wind Chill,'' let us first give thanks for what it isn't: a procession of teenage corpses, and, to avoid the more vulgar expression, torture-tainment. That said, let us give thanks for what it largely is: a moody, spooky tale, rendered with laudable economy.
Opened yesterday in New York, Los Angeles, Phoenix, Seattle, Dallas, Houston, Atlanta, Miami, Chicago and Minneapolis. Directed by Gregory Jacobs 87 minutes

Of Gregory Jacobs's thriller ''Wind Chill,'' let us first give thanks for what it isn't: a procession of teenage corpses, and, to avoid the more vulgar expression, torture-tainment. That said, let us give thanks for what it largely is: a moody, spooky tale, rendered with laudable economy.

A college student (Emily Blunt) hooks up with another (Ashton Holmes) for a ride home at Christmas break, and gradually learns of his hidden past. After a hit and run on a remote, snow-swept country road, the two discover that their route has its secrets too.

The principals' badinage has charm and understated perversity, and the production values display the finesse fitting a movie counting George Clooney and Steven Soderbergh among its producers. Though it reaches its climax, after the requisite jolts, with undue haste, ''Wind Chill'' mostly has a measured, frosty ambience that lets its performances warm the screen.

While Mr. Holmes vacillates fluidly between cherubic innocence and veiled menace, this is Ms. Blunt's movie. The actress, a strong asset in ''The Devil Wears Prada,'' has a winning way with melting hauteur, and she easily carries this spare diversion. Expect her to carry much bigger movies before long.
''Wind Chill'' is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has strong language and mild violence.
